sect1.title: Locating the Ceph Dashboard
sect1.para: If you are unsure of the location of the Ceph Dashboard, run the following command:
sect1.screen: cephuser@adm > ceph mgr services | grep dashboard "dashboard": "https://host:port"
sect1.para: The command returns the URL where the Ceph Dashboard is located: (https://host:port/)

sect1.title: Accessing the Ceph Dashboard
sect1.para: If you are unable to access the Ceph Dashboard, run through the following commands.

step.para: Verify the Ceph Dashboard module is enabled:
Ensure the Ceph Dashboard module is listed in the enabled_modules section. Example snipped output from the ceph mgr module ls command:
If it is not listed, activate the module with the following command:
step.screen: cephuser@adm > ceph mgr module enable dashboard

step.para: Check the Ceph Manager log file for any errors. To do this, first you will need the name of the Ceph Manager daemon. Find this with the cephadm ls command. It will return output similar to the following snippet:
You can then use the name given by the command above to view the log file:
Ensure the SSL/TSL support is configured properly:
step.screen: cephuser@adm > ceph config-key get mgr/dashboard/key cephuser@adm > ceph config-key get mgr/dashboard/crt

step.para: Verify the self-signed certificate exists. If not, run:
See for more information on self-signed certificates or for information on self-signed certificates by CA.

sect1.title: Troubleshooting logging into the Ceph Dashboard
sect1.para: If you are unable to log into the Ceph Dashboard and you receive the following error, run through the procedural checks below:

step.para: Check that your user credentials are correct. If you are seeing the notification message above when trying to log into the Ceph Dashboard, it is likely you are using the wrong credentials. Double check your username and password, and ensure the caps lock key is not enabled by accident.
If your user credentials are correct, but you are experiencing the same error, check that the user account exists:
This command returns your user data. If the user does not exist, it will print:
step.screen: Error ENOENT: User USERNAME does not exist
step.para: In this case, you will need to create the user. See for more information on user accounts.
Check if the user is enabled:
step.screen: cephuser@adm > ceph dashboard ac-user-show USERNAME {..., "enabled": true, ..}
step.para: Check if enabled is set to true for your user. If not the user is not enabled, run:

sect1.title: Determining if a Ceph Dashboard feature is not working
sect1.para: When an error occurs on the backend, you will usually receive an error notification on the frontend. Run through the following scenarios to debug.

step.para: Check the Ceph Dashboard/mgr logfile(s) for any errors. These can be identified by searching for keywords, such as 500 Internal Server Error, followed by traceback. The end of a traceback contains more details about what exact error occurred.
Check your web browser's Javascript Console for any errors.

sect2.title: Debugging the Ceph Dashboard flag
sect2.para: With this flag enabled, traceback of errors are included in backend responses.
To enable this flag via the Ceph Dashboard, navigate from Cluster to Manager modules. Select Dashboard module and click the edit button. Click the debug checkbox and update.
To enable via the CLI, run the following command:

sect2.title: Setting logging level of Ceph Dashboard module
sect2.para: Setting the logging level to debug makes the log more verbose and helpful for debugging.

step.para: Increase the logging level of manager daemons:
step.screen: cephuser@adm > ceph tell mgr config set debug_mgr 20

step.para: Adjust the logging level of the Ceph Dashboard module via the Ceph Dashboard or CLI:

listitem.para: Navigate from Cluster to Manager modules. Select Dashboard module and click the edit button. Modify the log_level configuration.
To adjust via the CLI, run the following command:
listitem.screen: cephuser@adm > bin/ceph config set mgr mgr/dashboard/log_level debug
